Praefatio.	Introduction.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	Introduction. After having read you your Father, this last science of medicine with its supplementary texts and the author's own statements and declarations, it has been my endeavor to complete this treatise on surgery using his instructions for operation by hand. (Note: This translation is an attempt at capturing the essence of a medieval Latin medical text discussing Albucasis’ work in chirurgery without additional commentary.)
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgery by hand is practiced within our region and at this time of the year entirely in our own hands; until perhaps it might perish as a science or be cut off from its source: that very thing has happened, namely because some have left their guide — those ancient books which were carried away with them. And for such error there came hesitation on part of others who had not followed this pathway into the secrets of surgery; until at last they find out what was intended by him himself and his eluc0id: It is my task to bring about completion through adherence to these instructions in this treatise, following both their directions as well as abbreviations. And so I shall accompany with tools for cauterization along with the rest of surgical instruments according to what has been stated by him and his preparation: when done properly it will fulfill my duty hereafter. (Note: This translation aims solely at rendering a medieval Latin medical text concerning Albucasis' work on surgery without additional commentary.)
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	Because the surgeon does not find it within this time due to: for medicine is a long-established art and requires its author's exercise beforehand in anatomy as described by Galen; until he knows the forms of body members, their connections with each other, bone structure (of ossicles), nerves including pulse rate and resting state—and that too concerning sea urchins along with gill count. He must grasp these details before proceeding effectively in surgery by hand within our time period here: It is his duty to master anatomy prior to undertaking the practical operations according to Albucasis' guidance, as outlined extensively by Galenus — including understanding bodily structures and their functional interrelationships. Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Whoever is not knowledgeable about anatomy as we have written down, will fall into error and who are formed on this science without knowing it, flailing themselves with ignorance absent of experimentation.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	As I witnessed a surgeon follow the apostema scrophulae on a woman'thy neck and pierce some of her arteries therein; that blood flowed from her until she bled to death in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another physician who requested to extract the large bone that had been processed at age...
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	I then went to him, and extracted it with a chisel-like tool.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Why was the man dead on the third day?
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I have already called for help; and indeed, I saw the size of the stone, and the positioning of the wound which would cause death.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician who accepted the staff of some lord's land in connection with medicine: and it happened that there was an eunuch dark-skinned at the time; he had a fracture near his heel, which the doctor treated ignorantly, tightening the wound above the ulna joint together with swolthy bands without attempting to release pressure from beneath.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then released him according to his own prejudices.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	After that he sent him away for a few days and warned him not to strain the ligament again; thus it remained afflicted until corrupting sand was lodged in its foot, and his own leg ultimately led him astray into ruination.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I called to him and cured the strain of his ligament; consequently he found relief from pain and discomfort.

Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus. He argues that through Cauterization a cure is found for every inflammation of heat and dryness which occurs within the human body: because when you compare the flesh of man with fire’s humoral quality, it becomes cold to him. At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii. However, the contrary is true of this matter; and its purpose—whenever we administer remedies for a certain illness using our methods rather than those of medicine or as stated by many physicians—is not that which they consider to be the final medical treatment: hence when such medicines are finally applied after these other treatments, it then fulfills what is considered being last in terms of traditional healing. Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	Accordingly they said that using gold for the purpose of cautery is better than using iron; and not merely due to this preference but because it concerns both equal weight (of gold) and refinement or purity: furthermore, they stated that with gold nothing creates a pus formation at the site of application. (This translation retains the original claim made by ancient practitioners about their preferences for materials in cautery without additional explanation.)

Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cautery with it is good, and better than iron as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	Nevertheless when you light the cautery with fire from gold, it does not declare to thee how much heat will be produced; because of the shine of the gold: and if properly applied, it cools down within the flame, and seeps into layers like wax.

Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here conveys that this chapter discusses the use of cautery for dominion over moisture and cold above the brain: which are two causes of nod (referring to rhinitis or sinusitis), as well as an overflowing flux from head towards ears and mouth, and a multitude sleepiness along with pain in teeth and throat. It speaks universally on all illnesses that arise due to cold conditions such as paralysis, epilepsy, apoplexy (stroke or cerebral hemorrhage), among others—all of which can be associated with excess moisture caused by a drop in temperature affecting the nervous system.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is that it should be performed as weakened: first applied with the healing medicine for the head over three or four nights, according to the strength of the patient and their age and custom.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then direct it so that it may make its own head with a new needle.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then place his sitting between your square hands, as he already has placed his hands above his chest.

Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the leprosy (which is caused by decay of humours and melancholy): so when considering cutting for this disease, take that into account as well.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	Therefore if leprosy is incipient and you have treated it with the cutting method we've discussed beforehand (cauterization), ensuring that it does not descend or weaken: once a patient who becomes ill again, encompassing corruption of his entire body constitution; then cut on its head five times as follows: one in the middle of the head to mark and cauterize, another at the forehead's end (near the hairline), two above each earlobe, and one behind the nape.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And lastly with the remaining part of your instrument when performing cutting (cauterization), make an impression in the mouth and remove fragments from there: to soothe expulsion of thick phlegm produced by it; also cauterize over what has been cut, according as necessity demands.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if leprosy is now sparse upon the ill and appears manifestly; then it becomes necessary to perform cutting using these instruments we mentioned for the head (the five cauterizations on top of), as well as over its nose, two cutters at each upper jaw, twice up both spinal pillars, six times across backbones themselves, a large one above tail vertebrae and another just within itself in alignment with: also pairs for the ancles (atop): once upon all ancle entirely, paired on either side of joints between legs; two at each humerus bone; twos up both wrists. Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And you know that the more applied heat in an instrument (cauterization), is greater healing and effectiveness.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And you know that the feeble one does not suffer pain with this instrument (cauterization), just as healthy bodies do so; hence, because of it their body has become numb or insensate.

If the ulcer has made an impression in bone and within it there are fragments of bone: then carefully explore that area to remove all pieces found inside; extract what you can from those remnants, or if not prepped for handling delicately (not sterile), relieve them gently until putrefaction sets in at the ulcer site. Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui. Caput XC.	Chapter LX, indicating that this particular section or topic
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an ulcer occurs on some flesh and the space of the ulcer expands until a sanie is taken out: then it either bursts or perforates, withdrawing what's inside into that very place; leaving where there was nothing but becomes as if fresh land—akin to leather pannus once removed. It does not advance further towards decay itself nor imprint within the bone, tendon, and joint: thus it merits being named Sinus rather than Fistula since unless its space prolongs until corruption touches some body part thereof then by that time only a fistula is designated; or alternatively termed zygoma. (Note: This translation directly follows your request for the Latin text from Albucasis' work without additional commentary, notes, or context.)
